adjective.definition: (typically of an artist or work of art) imitative of the work of another person, and usually disapproved of for that reason.
adjective.example: an artist who is not in the slightest bit derivative

noun.definition: Something that is based on another source.
noun.example: a derivative of the system was chosen for the Marine Corps’ V-22 tilt rotor aircraft

verb.definition: Remove the moisture from (something, especially food), typically in order to preserve it.
verb.example: desiccated coconut

verb.definition: Lacking interest, passion, or energy.
verb.example: a desiccated history of ideas

noun.definition: A state of disuse.
noun.example: the docks fell into desuetude

adjective.definition: Lacking a plan, purpose, or enthusiasm.
adjective.example: a few people were left, dancing in a desultory fashion

noun.definition: A thing that discourages or is intended to discourage someone from doing something.

adjective.definition: Able or intended to deter.
adjective.example: the deterrent effect of heavy prison sentences

adjective.definition: (especially of fabric) light, delicate, and translucent.
adjective.example: a diaphanous dress of pale gold

noun.definition: A forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something.
noun.example: a diatribe against the Roman Catholic Church

meaning: division into two usually contradictory parts

noun.definition: A division or contrast between two things that are or are represented as being opposed or entirely different.
noun.example: a rigid dichotomy between science and mysticism

noun.definition: Modesty or shyness resulting from a lack of self-confidence.
noun.example: I say this with some diffidence

verb.definition: Spread or cause to spread over a wide area or among a large number of people.
verb.example: technologies diffuse rapidly

adjective.definition: Spread out over a large area; not concentrated.
adjective.example: the diffuse community centered on the church

meaning: act of straying from the main point

noun.definition: A temporary departure from the main subject in speech or writing.
noun.example: let's return to the main topic after that brief digression

noun.definition: A lament for the dead, especially one forming part of a funeral rite.

verb.definition: Persuade (someone) that an idea or belief is mistaken.
verb.example: he quickly disabused me of my fanciful notions

meaning: perceptive; exhibiting keen insight and good judgement

adjective.definition: Having or showing good judgment.
adjective.example: the restaurant attracts discerning customers

verb.definition: Make (someone) feel uneasy or embarrassed.
verb.example: he was not noticeably discomfited by her tone

adjective.definition: Disagreeing or incongruous.
adjective.example: the principle of meritocracy is discordant with claims of inherited worth

adjective.definition: (of sounds) harsh and jarring because of a lack of harmony.
adjective.example: bombs, guns, and engines mingled in discordant sound

verb.definition: Harm the good reputation of (someone or something)
verb.example: his remarks were taken out of context in an effort to discredit him

noun.definition: Loss or lack of reputation or respect.
noun.example: they committed crimes that brought discredit upon the administration

noun.definition: A lack of compatibility or similarity between two or more facts.
noun.example: there's a discrepancy between your account and his

adjective.definition: Individually separate and distinct.
adjective.example: speech sounds are produced as a continuous sound signal rather than discrete units

meaning: quality of showing self-restraint in speech or actions

noun.definition: The quality of behaving or speaking in such a way as to avoid causing offense or revealing private information.
noun.example: she knew she could rely on his discretion

noun.definition: The freedom to decide what should be done in a particular situation.
noun.example: it is up to local authorities to use their discretion in setting the charges

adjective.definition: Not candid or sincere, typically by pretending that one knows less about something than one really does.
adjective.example: this journalist was being somewhat disingenuous as well as cynical

adjective.definition: Not influenced by considerations of personal advantage.
adjective.example: a banker is under an obligation to give disinterested advice

adjective.definition: Having or feeling no interest in something.
adjective.example: her father was so disinterested in her progress that he only visited the school once

adjective.definition: Lacking a coherent sequence or connection.
adjective.example: piecing together disjointed fragments of information

verb.definition: Order or allow to leave; send away.
verb.example: she dismissed the taxi at the corner of the road

verb.definition: Regard or represent as being of little worth.
verb.example: he never missed an opportunity to disparage his competitors

adjective.definition: Essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison.
adjective.example: they inhabit disparate worlds of thought

noun.definition: Things so unlike that there is no basis for comparison.

verb.definition: Conceal one's true motives, feelings, or beliefs.
verb.example: an honest, sincere person with no need to dissemble

verb.definition: Spread or disperse (something, especially information) widely.
verb.example: health authorities should foster good practice by disseminating information

noun.definition: The closing down or dismissal of an assembly, partnership, or official body.
noun.example: the dissolution of their marriage

noun.definition: Debauched living; dissipation.
noun.example: an advanced state of dissolution

noun.definition: Lack of harmony among musical notes.
noun.example: an unusual degree of dissonance for such choral styles

verb.definition: Swell or cause to swell by pressure from inside.
verb.example: the abdomen distended rapidly

verb.definition: Purify (a liquid) by vaporizing it, then condensing it by cooling the vapor, and collecting the resulting liquid.
verb.example: they managed to distill a small quantity of water

verb.definition: Extract the essential meaning or most important aspects of.
verb.example: my travel notes were distilled into a book

adjective.definition: Distracted or absentminded.
adjective.example: he seemed oddly distrait

meaning: to vary; go in different directions from the same point

verb.definition: (of a road, route, or line) separate from another route, especially a main one, and go in a different direction.
(of a series) increase indefinitely as more of its terms are added.
Deprive (someone) of power, rights, or possessions.
verb.example: men are unlikely to be divested of power without a struggle

meaning: to make known something that is secret

verb.definition: Make known (private or sensitive information)
verb.example: I do not want to divulge my plans at the moment

meaning: to provide with written evidence to support

noun.definition: A piece of written, printed, or electronic matter that provides information or evidence or that serves as an official record.

verb.definition: Record (something) in written, photographic, or other form.
verb.example: the photographer spent years documenting the lives of miners
synonyms: set down in black and white

noun.definition: Comic verse composed in irregular rhythm.

adjective.definition: Inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true.
adjective.example: he gives his opinion without trying to be dogmatic

adjective.definition: (of an animal) having normal physical functions suspended or slowed down for a period of time; in or as if in a deep sleep.
adjective.example: dormant butterflies

noun.definition: Something regarded as worthless; rubbish.
noun.example: there are bargains if you have the patience to sift through the dross

verb.definition: Deceive; trick.
verb.example: the newspaper was duped into publishing an untrue story

noun.definition: A victim of deception.
noun.example: knowing accomplices or unknowing dupes

verb & noun.definition: short for duplicate, especially in photography
verb & noun.example: how to dupe 35 mm slides on to 35 mm film

adjective.definition: Cheerful and full of energy.
adjective.example: she sounded ebullient and happy

adjective.definition: (of liquid or matter) boiling or agitated as if boiling.
adjective.example: misted and ebullient seas

adjective.definition: Deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
adjective.example: her musical tastes are eclectic

adjective.definition: Of, denoting, or belonging to a class of ancient philosophers who did not belong to or found any recognized school of thought but selected such doctrines as they wished from various schools.

noun.definition: A person who derives ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.

meaning: state of high spirits or liveliness; process of bubling as gas escapes

noun.definition: Bubbles in a liquid; fizz.
noun.example: the effervescence of sparkling wine

noun.definition: Vivacity and enthusiasm.
noun.example: he was filled with such effervescence

adjective.definition: (of a person) affected, overrefined, and ineffectual.
adjective.example: effete trendies from art college

noun.definition: A person who opposes official policy, especially that of an authoritarian state.
noun.example: a dissident who had been jailed by a military regime

adjective.definition: In opposition to official policy.
adjective.example: there is only one explicitly dissident voice to be heard

adjective.definition: Seeking to impose a doctrine in all circumstances without regard to practical considerations.
adjective.example: a doctrinaire conservative

noun.definition: A person who seeks to impose a doctrine without regard to practical considerations.
The ability to produce a desired or intended result.
noun.example: there is little information on the efficacy of this treatment

noun.definition: Insolent or impertinent behavior.
noun.example: one juror had the effrontery to challenge the coroner's decision

meaning: the tendency to see things in relation to oneself; self-centeredness

noun.definition: another term for egotism

adjective.definition: Excessively conceited or absorbed in oneself; self-centered.
adjective.example: he's selfish, egotistical, and arrogant

noun.definition: A poem of serious reflection, typically a lament for the dead.
(in Greek and Roman poetry) a poem written in elegiac couplets, as notably by Catullus and Propertius.

verb.definition: Evoke or draw out (a response, answer, or fact) from someone in reaction to one's own actions or questions.
verb.example: they invariably elicit exclamations of approval from guests

meaning: a sustance believed to have the power to cure ills

noun.definition: A magical or medicinal potion.
noun.example: an elixir guaranteed to induce love

noun.definition: A particular type of medicinal solution.
noun.example: a cough elixir

adjective.definition: Relating to or characteristic of heaven or paradise.
adjective.example: Elysian visions

adjective.definition: Abnormally thin or weak, especially because of illness or a lack of food.
adjective.example: she was so emaciated she could hardly stand

verb.definition: Make (something) more attractive by the addition of decorative details or features.
verb.example: blue silk embellished with golden embroidery

adjective.definition: Having the quality of softening or soothing the skin.
adjective.example: an emollient cream

noun.definition: A preparation that softens the skin.
noun.example: formulated with rich emollients

adjective.definition: Based on, concerned with, or verifiable by observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic.
adjective.example: they provided considerable empirical evidence to support their argument

verb.definition: Match or surpass (a person or achievement), typically by imitation.
verb.example: lesser men trying to emulate his greatness

noun.definition: A speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly.

adjective.definition: (of a disease or condition) regularly found among particular people or in a certain area.
adjective.example: complacency is endemic in industry today

adjective.definition: (of a plant or animal) native and restricted to a certain place.
adjective.example: a marsupial endemic to northeastern Australia

noun.definition: An endemic plant or animal.

verb.definition: Cause (someone) to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken.

adjective.definition: Lacking in energy or vitality.
adjective.example: the enervate slightness of his frail form

verb.definition: Cause or give rise to (a feeling, situation, or condition)
verb.example: the issue engendered continuing controversy

verb.definition: Intensify, increase, or further improve the quality, value, or extent of.
verb.example: his refusal does nothing to enhance his reputation

noun.definition: The branch of zoology concerned with the study of insects.

verb.definition: Say or pronounce clearly.
verb.example: she enunciated each word slowly

adjective.definition: Lasting for a very short time.
adjective.example: fashions are ephemeral

noun.definition: An ephemeral plant.

meaning: branch of philosophy tha texamines the nature of knowledge

noun.definition: The theory of knowledge, especially with regard to its methods, validity, and scope. Epistemology is the investigation of what distinguishes justified belief from opinion.

adjective.definition: (of a person) not easily disturbed or angered; calm and even-tempered.

noun.definition: Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.
noun.example: she accepted both the good and the bad with equanimity

verb.definition: Use ambiguous language so as to conceal the truth or avoid committing oneself.
verb.example: “Not that we are aware of,” she equivocated

meaning: mistaken; straying from the proper course

adjective.definition: Erring or straying from the proper course or standards.
adjective.example: he could never forgive his daughter's errant ways

adjective.definition: Traveling in search of adventure.
adjective.example: that same lady errant

adjective.definition: Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
adjective.example: Ken could turn any conversation into an erudite discussion

meaning: hard to understand; known only to a few

adjective.definition: Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest.
adjective.example: esoteric philosophical debates

meaning: to make an attempt; subject to a test

noun.definition: A short piece of writing on a particular subject.
An attempt or effort.
noun.example: a misjudged essay

verb.definition: Attempt or try.
verb.example: essay a smile

adjective.definition: Worthy of great respect.
adjective.example: she was shown into that estimable woman's presence

meaning: based on the attitude tha one's group is superior

adjective.definition: Evaluating other peoples and cultures according to the standards of one's own culture.

noun.definition: The cause, set of causes, or manner of causation of a disease or condition.
noun.example: a group of distinct diseases with different etiologies

noun.definition: The investigation or attribution of the cause or reason for something, often expressed in terms of historical or mythical explanation.

meaning: origin an history of a word

noun.definition: The study of the origin of words and the way in which their meanings have changed throughout history.
noun.example: the decline of etymology as a linguistic discipline

meaning: study of factors that influence the hereditary qualities of the human race and ways to improve those qualities

plural noun.definition: The science of improving a human population by controlled breeding to increase the occurrence of desirable heritable characteristics. Developed largely by Francis Galton as a method of improving the human race, it fell into disfavor only after the perversion of its doctrines by the Nazis.

meaning: high praise to a death person

noun.definition: A speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly, typically someone who has just died.
noun.example: his good friend delivered a brief eulogy

meaning: use of agreeable or inoffensive language in place of offensive language

noun.definition: A mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered to be too harsh or blunt when referring to something unpleasant or embarrassing.
noun.example: “downsizing” as a euphemism for cuts

noun.definition: A feeling or state of intense excitement and happiness.
noun.example: the euphoria of success will fuel your desire to continue training

noun.definition: The painless killing of a patient suffering from an incurable and painful disease or in an irreversible coma. The practice is illegal in most countries.

meaning: to show plainly; be an indication of

verb.definition: Reveal the presence of (a quality or feeling)
verb.example: his letters evince the excitement he felt at undertaking this journey

meaning: tending to call to mind or produce a reaction

adjective.definition: Bringing strong images, memories, or feelings to mind.
adjective.example: powerfully evocative lyrics

verb.definition: Make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.
verb.example: the exorbitant cost of land in urban areas only exacerbated the problem

meaning: to force the payment of; demand and obtain by authority

adjective.definition: Not approximated in any way; precise.
adjective.example: the exact details were still being worked out

verb.definition: Demand and obtain (something, especially a payment) from someone.
verb.example: tributes exacted from the Slavic peoples

verb.definition: Show or declare that (someone) is not guilty of wrongdoing.
verb.example: the article exculpated the mayor

adjective.definition: Extremely bad or unpleasant.
adjective.example: execrable cheap wine

verb.definition: Strongly encourage or urge (someone) to do something.
verb.example: “Come on, you guys,” exhorted Linda

noun.definition: An urgent need or demand.
noun.example: women worked long hours when the exigencies of the family economy demanded it

adjective.definition: Relating to existence.

meaning: to expel evil spirits; free from bad influences

verb.definition: Drive out or attempt to drive out (an evil spirit) from a person or place.
verb.example: an attempt to exorcise an unquiet spirit

meaning: to speak or write at length

verb.definition: Speak or write at length or in detail.
verb.example: she expatiated on working-class novelists

noun.definition: A person who lives outside their native country.
noun.example: American expatriates in London

adjective.definition: (of a person) living outside their native country.
adjective.example: expatriate writers and artists

verb.definition: Settle oneself abroad.
verb.example: candidates should be willing to expatriate

verb.definition: Atone for (guilt or sin)
verb.example: their sins must be expiated by sacrifice
